      • copy

        public EmptyIcon copy()
        Description copied from interface: CopyableIcon
        Returns a copy of this icon.

        The copy should be a new instance, it should preserve the original size and should paint equal to the original bitmap. The subtype of the new icon is up to an implementor. It may or may not be equal the original subtype.

        Specified by:
        copy in interface CopyableIcon

      • withIconPreScaled

        public EmptyIcon withIconPreScaled(boolean preScaled)
        Description copied from class: JBScalableIcon
        The pre-scaled state of the icon indicates whether the initial size of the icon is pre-scaled (by the global user scale) or not. If the size is not pre-scaled, then there're two approaches to deal with it: 1) scale its initial size right away and store; 2) scale its initial size every time it's requested. The 2nd approach is preferable because of the the following. Scaling of the icon may involve not only USR_SCALE but OBJ_SCALE as well. In which case applying all the scale factors and then rounding (the size is integer, the scale factors are not) gives more accurate result than rounding and then scaling.

        For example, say we have an icon of 15x15 initial size, USR_SCALE is 1.5f, OBJ_SCALE is 1,5f. Math.round(Math.round(15 * USR_SCALE) * OBJ_SCALE) = 35 Math.round(15 * USR_SCALE * OBJ_SCALE) = 34

        Thus, JBUI.scale(MyIcon.create(w, h)) is preferable to MyIcon.create(JBUI.scale(w), JBUI.scale(h)). Here [w, h] is "raw" unscaled size.

        Overrides:
        withIconPreScaled in class JBScalableIcon
        Parameters:
        preScaled - whether the icon is pre-scaled
        Returns:
        the icon in the provided pre-scaled state
        See Also:
        (JBScalableIcon)

      • updateScaleContext

        public boolean updateScaleContext(UserScaleContext ctx)
        Description copied from interface: ScaleContextAware
